Change has been successfully merged
This patch is related to the other ones in the chain, but does not directly build on the earlier patches in the chain.  I'm going to reorganize so that it's the first patch in the chain.
Done
This should be a constexpr array to avoid startup problems.
Alright I've made the change.
This almost definitely doesn't need to be aggregated because it's been deprecated in the standard.  I wonder if we should just strip @odata.context entirely in aggregated responses?

In general I don't think we should get into having aggregation stripping away deprecated properties and other fields from aggregated responses.  That seems like opening a big can of worms.

In this specific case it looks like the values would look like "/redfish/v1/$metadata#ComputerSystem.ComputerSystem".  That's not a format we can perform fixing on so it'd get left as is.  I might as well remove it from the list then since we'll never perform fixing on it.

> In general I don't think we should get into having aggregation stripping away deprecated properties and other fields from aggregated responses.

I agree with the statement you made, we shouldn't be stripping "Properties", of which this isn't a property, it's a metadata context that's supposed to relate to the ServiceRoot.  At best, forwarding it as-is is incorrect, because it can't be resolved post-aggregation.  That's why I'm suggesting removing it.  There's no "good" way to make it correct, and I'd rather it just not be there than be wrong.

>  That seems like opening a big can of worms.
> 
> In this specific case it looks like the values would look like "/redfish/v1/$metadata#ComputerSystem.ComputerSystem".  That's not a format we can perform fixing on so it'd get left as is.  I might as well remove it from the list then since we'll never perform fixing on it.

I still think we should remove it entirely, but we can take that up in another patch.  Removing it from the list is fine for this patch.
Done
This almost definitely doesn't need to be aggregated.  The hostname of the bmc doesn't change because it's been aggregated.

Alright I'll remove it and probably leave a comment justifying doing so.  Interesting sidenote: the hostname property for AggregationSource is of type "string (URI)", while the other instances of hostname property are only "string".
greeeeeeeeat.  Didn't realize we had that same property used in two places.  What a pain...
Is it only a pain because HostName doesn't have a consistent type?  For example, "@odata.id" and "@Redfish.ActionInfo" are both defined in different locations as a "string" and a "string (URI)".
No, it's a pain because Hostname exists in both AggregationSource, which should be aggregated, and in Manager, where it shouldn't' be aggregated.
Where did this come from?  I don't see it in 2022.2
That was supposed to be HttpBootUri.  It's since been removed as part of removing all properties that end in case-insensitive "uri".
This doesn't need aggregated.  "PublicationUri" is supposed to be world-facing.  Which brings up a fun problem of "we need to be able to identify non-relative URIs that don't point to this bmc".

That's a difficult problem.  The good news is I don't think we have to be that picky.  This change is only for fixing URIs in responses.  We won't ever forward requests for generic external URIs.  It's only for known Redfish URIs.

We call addPrefixToItem() to perform the actual fixing and it will only do that if the URI is for a known aggregated resource.  As part of that it must begin with /redfish/v1.  Public URIs won't fit that bill and thus be left as is.

> That's a difficult problem.  The good news is I don't think we have to be that picky.  This change is only for fixing URIs in responses.  We won't ever forward requests for generic external URIs.  It's only for known Redfish URIs.

Right, but PublicationUri will show up in a JsonSchema response.

> 
> We call addPrefixToItem() to perform the actual fixing and it will only do that if the URI is for a known aggregated resource.  As part of that it must begin with /redfish/v1.  Public URIs won't fit that bill and thus be left as is.

I THINK that solves it, so long as we're explicitly checking host() as well as path() and not just path (I think the common DMTF publication locations start with redfish/v1 as well)

> I THINK that solves it, so long as we're explicitly checking host() as well as path() and not just path (I think the common DMTF publication locations start with redfish/v1 as well)

These are examples from https://www.dmtf.org/sites/default/files/standards/documents/DSP2046_2022.2.pdf#page=366:
"PublicationUri": "http://redfish.dmtf.org/schemas/v1/Chassis.v1_11_0.json"
"PublicationUri": "http://schemas.contoso.com/Chassis.v1_11_0.xy.json"

We call parse_relative_ref() on the string and that doesn't extract the path.  If the URI begins with something like "http://" then it fails to parse and we return early.  Interestingly, a string like "www.redfish.dmtf.org/redfish/v1/Chassis" will parse.  However, after converting to url_view the entire path is recognized as "www.redfish.dmtf.org/redfish/v1/Chassis" so we wouldn't apply a prefix in that scenario either.
ACK

The future proofing you describe happens in line 141 where you posted a different comment https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/58937/comments/414be755_c59bf4ce.

I've moved this check into its own function just to make it clearer what's going on.
Wait.... we already do the above.....   Maybe that list just needs culled?

This is for future proofing purposes.  I wanted the list to be exhaustive so that's why there is some redundancy.  I know that currently that means this check will never actually return true since the first part of the if statement will catch all existing properties.

I'll just go ahead and remove the redundancies from the list now that it is no longer an unordered_set.  That'll also help speed up the lookup process now that it's using binary search.
Same as below, pretty sure we don't want to fixup this one either, given that this is for EventService

I describe this in a latter comment, but it's not possible to fixup URIs that are not for known redfish resources.  I'll go ahead and remove it though since "Destination" won't point to a Redfish URI.
Done
Done
I don't think this is valid odata?
Yeah that's a really weird looking one, but it's defined in the spec as a "string (URI)" so I included it https://www.dmtf.org/sites/default/files/standards/documents/DSP2046_2022.2.pdf#page=47

Interesting.... I'm pretty sure that's a typo in the schema guide generation.  Lets leave it off for now, and I'll file a bug with DMTF.

https://github.com/DMTF/Redfish/issues/5372
Alright I've commented it out while the bug works its way through.
Yep, Jeff pushed a fix to the documentation.  WE should be good now.
Nice then I'll completely remove it instead of just commenting it out.
Aggregating async Tasks needs more thought than this.  I suspect we should omit this for now, but very likely the aggregator TaskService will need a special implementation for aggregation.

I'm not understanding the concern.  TaskMonitor only appears in responses from /redfish/v1/TaskService/Tasks/{TaskId}.  That can be an aggregated resource since Tasks is a top level collection.

The example in the schema is:
"TaskMonitor": "/taskmon/545"

That path would not get modified by the prefix fixing logic.

TaskMonitor points to a URI that is outside of the redfish tree, and has task monitor semantics, rather than normal redfish tree semantics.  If you aggregate a TaskMonitor URI per the normal rules, the TaskMonitor will be broken and non-functional.

In theory, for async tasks, the aggregator connection needs to have special handling for it, and integrate the Async tasks into the aggregated collection.  This is likely non-trivial, but will need to be done at some point.

> TaskMonitor points to a URI that is outside of the redfish tree, and has task monitor semantics, rather than normal redfish tree semantics
That doesn't seem to always be the case.  Right now we set TaskMonitor as /redfish/v1/TaskService/Tasks/<TaskId>/Monitor https://github.com/openbmc/bmcweb/blob/master/redfish-core/lib/task.hpp#L407-L411.  We would want to fixup that link since we'll be able to aggregate it when this chain of patches lands.

> If you aggregate a TaskMonitor URI per the normal rules, the TaskMonitor will be broken and non-functional.
We won't aggregate any URI that is not part of a top level collection in the Redfish tree.  If it's an external URI then the prefix fixing logic would ignore it anyway.  If there's a situation where the URI is not in the redfish tree, but it's somehow local to the satellite BMC, then I'm not sure how we'd handle aggregating requests to it.  BMCWeb wouldn't normally handle ones outside of the redfish tree.

> In theory, for async tasks, the aggregator connection needs to have special handling for it, and integrate the Async tasks into the aggregated collection.  This is likely non-trivial, but will need to be done at some point.
That should get implemented as part of https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/59004/10.  The URI for a given satellite Task will be /redfish/v1/TaskService/Tasks/{TaskId}.  /redfish/v1/TaskService/Tasks is a top level collection and as such the satellite task will be exposed as /redfish/v1/TaskService/Tasks/{prefix}_{TaskID}.

> > TaskMonitor points to a URI that is outside of the redfish tree, and has task monitor semantics, rather than normal redfish tree semantics
> That doesn't seem to always be the case.  Right now we set TaskMonitor as /redfish/v1/TaskService/Tasks/<TaskId>/Monitor https://github.com/openbmc/bmcweb/blob/master/redfish-core/lib/task.hpp#L407-L411.  We would want to fixup that link since we'll be able to aggregate it when this chain of patches lands.

Right, but you have to realize that /redfish/v1/TaskService/Tasks/<TaskId>/Monitor is something that openbmc picked, and while the URI looks like it's in the redfish tree (which we do for peoples sanity) it's actually not a Redfish CRUD node.  With that said, maybe aggregating it would give the right behavior?  This needs more thought.

> 
> > If you aggregate a TaskMonitor URI per the normal rules, the TaskMonitor will be broken and non-functional.
> We won't aggregate any URI that is not part of a top level collection in the Redfish tree.  If it's an external URI then the prefix fixing logic would ignore it anyway.  If there's a situation where the URI is not in the redfish tree, but it's somehow local to the satellite BMC, then I'm not sure how we'd handle aggregating requests to it.  BMCWeb wouldn't normally handle ones outside of the redfish tree.

I suspect we need to just not aggregate it or omit it, but lets discuss in a future patch.

> 
> > In theory, for async tasks, the aggregator connection needs to have special handling for it, and integrate the Async tasks into the aggregated collection.  This is likely non-trivial, but will need to be done at some point.
> That should get implemented as part of https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/59004/10.  The URI for a given satellite Task will be /redfish/v1/TaskService/Tasks/{TaskId}.  /redfish/v1/TaskService/Tasks is a top level collection and as such the satellite task will be exposed as /redfish/v1/TaskService/Tasks/{prefix}_{TaskID}.

Right, but the task monitor isn't going to forward correctly, because the task monitor could be something totally different.

oh well, problem for another day.  I'm satisfied.

> oh well, problem for another day.  I'm satisfied.

SGTM.  This will likely come up again as part of the patch I previously linked which adds support for all top level collections.  Per offline discussion, the play might be to just completely strip TaskMonitor from responses and then create a future patch which would implement some type of special handling for the URI.
A couple super nit picks (feel free to ignore if you want) and one function that could use a unit test, and this is good to go.
Can we get a unit test case or two for this method?  Just 3-4 examples of properties should be fine.
nit, normally we don't pass string_views by const.  Up to you.
Sure, let me see about setting this up.
Done
nit, extra parens.
Done
This dependency was needed in order for the new test to build
